Your opinion is too warped by your complete lack of experience with rpgs, especially jrpgs. Yes it is pretty common, especially in older titles. Back in the day people used to spend a lot more time on specific titles and not just jump to the next game as soon as credits roll, especially RPG fans, both for lack of money and titles. Also post-game is areas and content that is either of higher difficulty and optional stuff that are geared towards other aspects of the game like PvP training instead of the main story experience.
Because you also touch a bit on the linearity of these games, and since we got the first fully open world pokemon game, linearity isn't a god damn flaw. But at least you admit that you'd need a lot of time to implement something like it. To make a good open world game, you actually need to consider all the possible paths a player can take. The game might be open world with a lot of options, but the devs should have designed with all of those options in mind which is extremely hard and takes a lot of time. Rather than that though we get served the garbage open world that Bethesda popularized. Worst timeline.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52373867
And JRPGs that don't put stuff into a post-game tend to suffer for it. Take Xenoblade 2 as an example of something that initially had no post-game content. The superbosses appear upon entering the final area, not beating the final boss. But if you're the kind of player who tries to complete every side quest, unlock every character, do everything you can do before beating the main story, you will end up grossly overleveled by the time you reach the final area, and by that point you may as well do the superbosses and all the unique monsters before the final boss. Xenoblade 3 paces it a lot better by giving you a post-game where you can even delevel which becomes the optimal way to max out all your character classes. Certain characters are even locked behind the post-game despite appearing in the main story because the reveal that they can be used in the final battle is a huge surprise, and a certain reveal in the ending adds much more weight and context to a post-game quest.

Post-game should be used to pace story and content. I think that features like transferring Pokémon ahead should be locked behind post-game because it gives the player too many options to have their level 70 Rayquaza available in the main game. Pokémon is famously a series where fans have to continuously jump through more and more hoops with each iteration to do challenge runs. And I don't mean hard mode where losing occasionally is possible, I mean a challenge run is simply "Don't lose a single battle while under tons of handicaps", that's what has to be done to make Pokémon engaging in terms of challenge. Legendary Pokémon tied to post-game dungeons is good design because these are the bigger rewards for playing through the game. Due to the nature of the Pokédex, Pokémon has an open-ended structure and begs for a post-game.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Welcome to the Raidcat / 6 Star Tera Raid Meta Thread

>lol I can solo 5 star raids I don't need your ugly cat
6 stars are infinitely harder than 5 and extremely annoying. You can do them the normal way and risk wasting your time, or accept the raidcat as your raid savior.

>What's the meta?
4 Perrserkers. Their Hidden Ability stacks multiplicatively and, if you follow the flowchart, you can one-shot most raids.

>What's the raidcat like?
Perrserker @ Lum Berry
Level 100
Ability: Steely Spirit (Hidden Ability)
EVs: 252 Atk / 252 Speed (Host) or HP (Joiner)
Adamant Nature
- Iron Head
- Screech
- Swords Dance
- Taunt (Host) / Helping Hand (Joiner)

>Host? Joiner? Flowchart?
There's a small difference in strategy whether you are hosting or joining a raid and a specific flowchart. See OP pic.

>Does this work every time?
No, but it's one of the only consistent strategies that you can follow. It's not great against Pokemon that have strong and/or STAB Fire/Fighting/Ground moves, and if their Tera resists Steel it can also take a few more turn (but still doable).

>So what's the hype?
Catraids are simple to organize, have plenty of flowcharts, and finish the job very quickly. It's about efficiency.

>I have a question about raids...
Check OP pic.

>How to get cat with HA?
Language Teacher sidequest, then use an Ability Patch to change its ability. Patch is an 11% drop from 6 Star Raids.

>I tried breeding but I'm getting Kantonian Meowth
Make the G-Meowth hold an Everstone

>wtf I did that but none of them have Steely Spirit
G-Meowth's HA is Unnerve, it becomes Steely Spirit upon evolution.

For other viable meta strategies and mons, Ctrl+F OTHERMONS

For specific strategies, Ctrl+F HARDRAIDS

Use this thread to trade for raidcats, to organize (raidcat) raids, or just to discuss and ask questions about raids in general.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Pokémon Artist Reportedly Designed Blaziken To Test Fan Reception. Did you shove it in a PC box?
threads.com:
According to YouTube channel Did You Know Gaming, Blaziken was the very first Pokémon designed for Ruby and Sapphire's Hoenn region, with Sugimori using its design as a test for players to see whether they would keep it in their party or simply shove it in a PC box. In a translated interview with Sugimori from a 2003 issue of 'Nintendo Dream' magazine, he states:

"I thought about how wide the variety of Pokémon could be and wanted to push the envelope of what would be accepted. So the first one I made was Blaziken. I wondered if people would go for such a humanoid Pokémon, I was intentionally testing the waters. Over the years we've developed an image of what a Pokémon looks like, but this time we decided to push those boundaries and weaken the idea of what can't be a Pokémon. Ruby and Sapphire was [about] taking on new inspirations for Pokémon unlike anything we used before."

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I still like it. It's a monster chicken.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>52372387
Did You Know Gaming goes on to say that Torchic's design was finalised after Blaziken's and was actually based on the phenomenon of 'painted chicks', which were sold frequently to children much in the same way that a goldfish would be. Apparently, once the painted chick grows up and either loses its coloured plumage or its natural cute looks, children would grow bored and throw them out (pretty horrid notion, if you ask us).

Sugimori states that this mentality towards painted chicks is what inspired Torchic and Blaziken, in that Torchic "starts out cute then grows into something fierce and hard to look at". In a sense, he was looking to potential replicate the feeling that an owner of a painted chick would feel once it grows up and is no longer deemed cute.

So the question is, did you keep Blaziken in your Pokémon party, or did you ditch it in a PC box for the rest of time? Based on Sugimori's commentary on the matter, we imagine a few of you might be feeling an overwhelming sense of shame right about now...

https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2022/07/random-pokemon-artist-reportedly-designed-blaziken-to-test-fan-reception#:%7E:text=Apparently%2C%20however%2C%20long%2Dtime,a%20more%20humanoid%20looking%20Pok%C3%A9mon
